ChatGPT said:

To create a ProtectedRoute component in React Router v6 that only protects the "dashboard" element when the user is logged in, you need to update your code accordingly. In React Router v6, the Route component has a different API compared to previous versions, and Navigate is used for programmatic navigation.

Here's how you can modify your ProtectedRoute component:

Updated ProtectedRoute Component

javascript
// components/ProtectedRoute.js
import React from 'react';
import { Navigate } from 'react-router-dom';

const ProtectedRoute = ({ isLoggedIn, element }) => {
  return isLoggedIn ? element : <Navigate to="/signIn" />;
};

export default ProtectedRoute;

How to Use ProtectedRoute in Your Routes

You would use the ProtectedRoute component in your routing configuration like this:

javascript
// App.js or your main routing file
import React from 'react';
import { BrowserRouter as Router, Routes, Route } from 'react-router-dom';
import ProtectedRoute from './components/ProtectedRoute';
import Dashboard from './components/Dashboard';
import SignIn from './components/SignIn';

const App = () => {
  const isLoggedIn = /* your logic to check if the user is logged in */;

  return (
    <Router>
      <Routes>
        <Route path="/signIn" element={<SignIn />} />
        <Route
          path="/dashboard"
          element={<ProtectedRoute isLoggedIn={isLoggedIn} element={<Dashboard />} />}
        />
      </Routes>
    </Router>
  );
};

export default App;

Explanation

  1. ProtectedRoute Component: This component checks if the user is logged in (isLoggedIn). If true, it renders the element prop; otherwise, it redirects the user to the /signIn page using the <Navigate> component.

  2. App.js Configuration: In your routing setup (App.js or similar), you use the ProtectedRoute for the /dashboard route. It ensures that the Dashboard component is only accessible if isLoggedIn is true.

By setting up your routes this way, you protect the "dashboard" route, ensuring only logged-in users can access it.

ChatGPT said:

Your SignIn component is well-structured for a simple login form. To make this component fully functional, we need to implement the authentication logic within the handleSubmit function. Below is the updated code with a simple authentication mechanism, saving user data in localStorage, and displaying error messages.

Updated SignIn Component

javascript
// components/SignIn.js
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import { useNavigate } from 'react-router-dom';

const SignIn = () => {
  const [email, setEmail] = useState('');
  const [password, setPassword] = useState('');
  const [error, setError] = useState('');
  const navigate = useNavigate(); // Initialize useNavigate for programmatic navigation

  const handleSubmit = (e) => {
    e.preventDefault();

    // Dummy validation (replace with real validation)
    if (email === 'test@example.com' && password === 'password') {
      // Save user data in localStorage
      localStorage.setItem('user', JSON.stringify({ email }));
      localStorage.setItem('isLoggedIn', 'true');

      // Redirect to dashboard after successful login
      navigate('/dashboard');
    } else {
      setError('Invalid email or password'); // Show an error message if validation fails
    }
  };

  return (
    <div className="signin-container">
      <h2>Sign In</h2>
      <form onSubmit={handleSubmit}>
        <div className="form-group">
          <label htmlFor="email">Email:</label>
          <input
            type="email"
            id="email"
            value={email}
            onChange={(e) => setEmail(e.target.value)}
            required
          />
        </div>
        <div className="form-group">
          <label htmlFor="password">Password:</label>
          <input
            type="password"
            id="password"
            value={password}
            onChange={(e) => setPassword(e.target.value)}
            required
          />
        </div>
        {error && <p className="error">{error}</p>} {/* Display error message if needed */}
        <button type="submit">Sign In</button>
      </form>
    </div>
  );
};

export default SignIn;

Key Changes Made

  1. useNavigate Hook:

    • This hook from react-router-dom is used for programmatic navigation. After a successful login, the user is redirected to the /dashboard route.

  2. Local Storage:

    • Upon successful authentication, the users email and a logged-in state are stored in localStorage. This is a basic way to persist login state across page reloads.

  3. Error Handling:

    • An error message is displayed if the authentication fails.

Notes:

  • Dummy Authentication: The current implementation uses dummy data for validation (email === 'test@example.com' and password === 'password'). This should be replaced with real authentication logic, such as making an API call to your backend.

  • Local Storage: Storing authentication data like this is simple but not secure for production applications. For real-world applications, consider using secure tokens and server-side sessions.

  • Styling: Make sure you have styles defined for .signin-container, .form-group, and .error to improve the user experience.

This setup allows for a simple, functional login form with basic validation and navigation.

You said:
withou local storage
ChatGPT said:

If you prefer to manage the authentication state without using localStorage, you can keep the authentication state in a higher-level component, such as your main App component. This way, the authentication state is maintained in the app's memory and reset upon page refresh, which can be more secure but means the user will need to log in again if the page is reloaded.

Heres how you can update your SignIn component and your App component to manage authentication without using localStorage.

Updated SignIn Component

javascript
// components/SignIn.js
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import { useNavigate } from 'react-router-dom';

const SignIn = ({ onLogin }) => { // Receive onLogin as a prop
  const [email, setEmail] = useState('');
  const [password, setPassword] = useState('');
  const [error, setError] = useState('');
  const navigate = useNavigate();

  const handleSubmit = (e) => {
    e.preventDefault();

    // Dummy validation (replace with real validation)
    if (email === 'test@example.com' && password === 'password') {
      onLogin(); // Call the onLogin function if validation is successful
      navigate('/dashboard'); // Redirect to dashboard after successful login
    } else {
      setError('Invalid email or password'); // Show an error message if validation fails
    }
  };

  return (
    <div className="signin-container">
      <h2>Sign In</h2>
      <form onSubmit={handleSubmit}>
        <div className="form-group">
          <label htmlFor="email">Email:</label>
          <input
            type="email"
            id="email"
            value={email}
            onChange={(e) => setEmail(e.target.value)}
            required
          />
        </div>
        <div className="form-group">
          <label htmlFor="password">Password:</label>
          <input
            type="password"
            id="password"
            value={password}
            onChange={(e) => setPassword(e.target.value)}
            required
          />
        </div>
        {error && <p className="error">{error}</p>} {/* Display error message if needed */}
        <button type="submit">Sign In</button>
      </form>
    </div>
  );
};

export default SignIn;

Updated App Component

In your main application component, you can manage the authentication state with useState.

javascript
// App.js
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import { BrowserRouter as Router, Routes, Route } from 'react-router-dom';
import ProtectedRoute from './components/ProtectedRoute';
import Dashboard from './components/Dashboard';
import SignIn from './components/SignIn';

const App = () => {
  const [isLoggedIn, setIsLoggedIn] = useState(false); // State to manage login status

  const handleLogin = () => {
    setIsLoggedIn(true); // Set logged-in status to true
  };

  return (
    <Router>
      <Routes>
        <Route path="/signIn" element={<SignIn onLogin={handleLogin} />} />
        <Route
          path="/dashboard"
          element={<ProtectedRoute isLoggedIn={isLoggedIn} element={<Dashboard />} />}
        />
      </Routes>
    </Router>
  );
};

export default App;

Explanation

  1. onLogin Prop: The SignIn component receives an onLogin function as a prop from the App component. When the user successfully logs in, this function is called to update the login state.

  2. handleLogin Function: This function updates the isLoggedIn state to true. Its passed to the SignIn component as a prop and called when the login is successful.

  3. State Management: The isLoggedIn state is managed at the App level, which allows other components to check the authentication status. When isLoggedIn is true, the ProtectedRoute will render the Dashboard component. If isLoggedIn is false, it will redirect to the sign-in page.

This approach keeps the authentication state within the app's runtime memory and avoids using localStorage, making it ideal for scenarios where you want the state to reset on page refresh or if you are not concerned about session persistence across page reloads.

  return (
    <Router>
      <Routes>
        <Route path="/about-us" element={<AboutUs />} />
      </Routes>
    </Router>
  );
};

ChatGPT said:

Heres a "Contact Us" page for your fitness challenge tracker using React:

React Component Code

jsx
// components/ContactUs.js
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import './ContactUs.css'; // Import the CSS file for styling

const ContactUs = () => {
  const [formData, setFormData] = useState({
    name: '',
    email: '',
    message: ''
  });

  const [submitted, setSubmitted] = useState(false);

  const handleChange = (e) => {
    const { name, value } = e.target;
    setFormData((prevData) => ({ ...prevData, [name]: value }));
  };

  const handleSubmit = (e) => {
    e.preventDefault();
    // Perform form submission logic (e.g., send to server)
    setSubmitted(true);
  };

  return (
    <div className="contact-us-container">
      <h1>Contact Us</h1>
      {!submitted ? (
        <form onSubmit={handleSubmit}>
          <div className="form-group">
            <label htmlFor="name">Name:</label>
            <input
              type="text"
              id="name"
              name="name"
              value={formData.name}
              onChange={handleChange}
              required
            />
          </div>
          <div className="form-group">
            <label htmlFor="email">Email:</label>
            <input
              type="email"
              id="email"
              name="email"
              value={formData.email}
              onChange={handleChange}
              required
            />
          </div>
          <div className="form-group">
            <label htmlFor="message">Message:</label>
            <textarea
              id="message"
              name="message"
              value={formData.message}
              onChange={handleChange}
              required
            ></textarea>
          </div>
          <button type="submit">Submit</button>
        </form>
      ) : (
        <p>Thank you for contacting us! We will get back to you soon.</p>
      )}
    </div>
  );
};

export default ContactUs;

ChatGPT said:

To place the icons inside the input boxes, you can use Material-UI's InputAdornment component along with TextField for styling the input fields. The InputAdornment component allows you to add an icon or text inside the input field.

Heres the updated ContactUs.js component with icons inside the input boxes:

Updated ContactUs.js Component

jsx
// components/ContactUs.js
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import PersonIcon from '@mui/icons-material/Person';
import EmailIcon from '@mui/icons-material/Email';
import LocalPhoneIcon from '@mui/icons-material/LocalPhone';
import MessageIcon from '@mui/icons-material/Message';
import { TextField, InputAdornment, Button } from '@mui/material';

const Contact = () => {
  const [formData, setFormData] = useState({
    name: '',
    email: '',
    contact: '',
    message: ''
  });

  const [submitted, setSubmitted] = useState(false);

  const handleChange = (e) => {
    const { name, value } = e.target;
    setFormData((prevData) => ({ ...prevData, [name]: value }));
  };

  const handleSubmit = (e) => {
    e.preventDefault();
    // Perform form submission logic (e.g., send to server)
    setSubmitted(true);
  };

  return (
    <div className="contact-us-container">
      <h1>Contact Us</h1>
      {!submitted ? (
        <form onSubmit={handleSubmit}>
          <div className="form-group">
            <TextField
              label="Name"
              id="name"
              name="name"
              value={formData.name}
              onChange={handleChange}
              required
              fullWidth
              InputProps={{
                startAdornment: (
                  <InputAdornment position="start">
                    <PersonIcon />
                  </InputAdornment>
                ),
              }}
              variant="outlined"
              margin="normal"
            />
          </div>
          <div className="form-group">
            <TextField
              label="Email"
              type="email"
              id="email"
              name="email"
              value={formData.email}
              onChange={handleChange}
              required
              fullWidth
              InputProps={{
                startAdornment: (
                  <InputAdornment position="start">
                    <EmailIcon />
                  </InputAdornment>
                ),
              }}
              variant="outlined"
              margin="normal"
            />
          </div>
          <div className="form-group">
            <TextField
              label="Contact"
              id="contact"
              name="contact"
              value={formData.contact}
              onChange={handleChange}
              required
              fullWidth
              InputProps={{
                startAdornment: (
                  <InputAdornment position="start">
                    <LocalPhoneIcon />
                  </InputAdornment>
                ),
              }}
              variant="outlined"
              margin="normal"
            />
          </div>
          <div className="form-group">
            <TextField
              label="Message"
              id="message"
              name="message"
              value={formData.message}
              onChange={handleChange}
              required
              fullWidth
              multiline
              rows={4}
              InputProps={{
                startAdornment: (
                  <InputAdornment position="start">
                    <MessageIcon />
                  </InputAdornment>
                ),
              }}
              variant="outlined"
              margin="normal"
            />
          </div>
          <Button variant="contained" color="primary" type="submit">
            Submit
          </Button>
        </form>
      ) : (
        <p>Thank you for contacting us! We will get back to you soon.</p>
      )}
    </div>
  );
};

export default Contact;

Explanation

  1. TextField Component: Replaces the standard HTML input and textarea elements with Material-UI's TextField component for better styling and functionality.

CSS Styling (Optional)

You can further customize the styles using CSS or by applying styles directly to the Material-UI components using the sx prop or style prop.

This setup integrates Material-UI components and icons seamlessly into your form, giving it a modern and professional look.

To add a background image to the .contact-us-container in your ContactUs component, you can update the CSS for this class to include a background-image property. Heres how you can modify your CSS to include a background image:

CSS with Background Image

css

  max-width: 600px;

}

Explanation of Added Properties:

  1. background-image: url('path-to-your-image.jpg');: Sets the background image of the container. Replace 'path-to-your-image.jpg' with the actual path to your image.

  2. background-size: cover;: Ensures the background image covers the entire container, maintaining its aspect ratio.

  3. background-position: center;: Centers the background image within the container.

  4. background-repeat: no-repeat;: Prevents the background image from repeating, ensuring it displays as a single image.

  background-repeat: no-repeat;

ChatGPT said:

To add a background image to the entire page or a specific section, such as the area around the "Contact Us" box, you'll want to apply the background image to a parent container or to the entire page itself, rather than to the .contact-us-container. Here's how you can set a background image for the entire page or the parent container that includes the "Contact Us" form.

Step-by-Step Instructions

  1. Applying Background Image to the Whole Page:

    If you want the background image to cover the entire page, you can apply the CSS styles to the body tag.

    css
    body {
  background-image: url('path-to-your-image.jpg'); /* Path to your background image */
  background-size: cover; /* Ensures the background image covers the entire screen */
  background-position: center; /* Centers the background image */
  background-repeat: no-repeat; /* Prevents the background image from repeating */
  margin: 0; /* Removes default margin */
  font-family: Arial, sans-serif; /* Sets default font */
}

  2. Applying Background Image to a Parent Container:

    If you want the background image to cover only a specific section that wraps your ContactUs component, you can add a parent container with its own styling.

    jsx
    // components/ContactUs.js
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import PersonIcon from '@mui/icons-material/Person';
import EmailIcon from '@mui/icons-material/Email';
import LocalPhoneIcon from '@mui/icons-material/LocalPhone';
import MessageIcon from '@mui/icons-material/Message';
import { Layout } from './Layout';

const Contact = () => {
  const [formData, setFormData] = useState({
    name: '',
    email: '',
    contact: '',
    message: ''
  });

  const [submitted, setSubmitted] = useState(false);

  const handleChange = (e) => {
    const { name, value } = e.target;
    setFormData((prevData) => ({ ...prevData, [name]: value }));
  };

  const handleSubmit = (e) => {
    e.preventDefault();
    // Perform form submission logic (e.g., send to server)
    setSubmitted(true);
  };

  return (
    <Layout>
      {/* Parent container for background image */}
      <div className="contact-us-background">
        <div className="contact-us-container">
          <h1>Contact Us</h1>
          {!submitted ? (
            <form onSubmit={handleSubmit}>
              <div className="form-group">
                <label htmlFor="name">Name:</label>
                <input
                  type="text"
                  id="name"
                  name="name"
                  value={formData.name}
                  onChange={handleChange}
                  required
                />
                <PersonIcon />
              </div>
              <div className="form-group">
                <label htmlFor="email">Email:</label>
                <input
                  type="email"
                  id="email"
                  name="email"
                  value={formData.email}
                  onChange={handleChange}
                  required
                />
                <EmailIcon />
              </div>
              <div className="form-group">
                <label htmlFor="contact">Contact:</label>
                <input
                  type="text"
                  id="contact"
                  name="contact"
                  value={formData.contact}
                  onChange={handleChange}
                  required
                />
                <LocalPhoneIcon />
              </div>
              <div className="form-group">
                <label htmlFor="message">Message:</label>
                <textarea
                  id="message"
                  name="message"
                  value={formData.message}
                  onChange={handleChange}
                  required
                ></textarea>
                <MessageIcon />
              </div>
              <button type="submit">Submit</button>
            </form>
          ) : (
            <p>Thank you for contacting us! We will get back to you soon.</p>
          )}
        </div>
      </div>
    </Layout>
  );
};

export default Contact;

    css
    /* In your CSS file */

.contact-us-background {
  background-image: url('path-to-your-image.jpg'); /* Path to your background image */
  background-size: cover; /* Ensures the background image covers the entire container */
  background-position: center; /* Centers the background image */
  background-repeat: no-repeat; /* Prevents the background image from repeating */
  padding: 40px 0; /* Adds padding to the top and bottom */
}

.contact-us-container {
  max-width: 600px;
  margin: 0 auto;
  padding: 20px;
  font-family: Arial, sans-serif;
  color: #333;
  border: 1px solid #ddd;
  border-radius: 8px;
  box-shadow: 0 4px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1);
  background-color: #fff; /* Ensures the contact form has a white background */
}

Explanation:

  • contact-us-background: This parent container class applies the background image to the entire section that wraps around your "Contact Us" form. The image will cover the entire container due to background-size: cover.

  • contact-us-container: The .contact-us-container remains styled as before, with a white background and other properties, ensuring the form itself stands out against the background image.

This approach gives you a flexible layout where the background image can be set independently of the form content.

jsx
// components/LogForm.js
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import { TextField, Button, Box, Container } from '@mui/material';
import { Layout } from './Layout';
import sideImg from '../assets/bg.jpeg'; // Ensure this path is correct

const LogForm = ({ addActivity }) => {
  const [formState, setFormState] = useState({
    date: '',
    steps: '',
    calories: '',
    workoutTime: ''
  });

  const handleChange = (e) => {
    const { name, value } = e.target;
    setFormState({
      ...formState,
      [name]: value
    });
  };

  const handleSubmit = (e) => {
    e.preventDefault();
    console.log('Form Submitted:', formState); // Debugging: Check if the form is being submitted
    addActivity(formState);
    setFormState({ date: '', steps: '', calories: '', workoutTime: '' });
  };

  return (
    <Layout>
      <Container className="form-wrapper">
        <div className="image-container">
          <img src={sideImg} alt="Fitness" />
        </div>
        <div className="form-container">
          <h1>Add Daily Activity</h1>
          <form onSubmit={handleSubmit}>
            <Box mb={2}>
              <TextField
                label="Date"
                name="date"
                value={formState.date}
                onChange={handleChange}
                fullWidth
                margin="normal"
                required
              />
              <TextField
                label="Steps Taken"
                name="steps"
                value={formState.steps}
                onChange={handleChange}
                fullWidth
                margin="normal"
                required
              />
              <TextField
                label="Calories Burned"
                name="calories"
                value={formState.calories}
                onChange={handleChange}
                fullWidth
                margin="normal"
                required
              />
              <TextField
                label="Workout Time (mins)"
                name="workoutTime"
                value={formState.workoutTime}
                onChange={handleChange}
                fullWidth
                margin="normal"
                required
              />
            </Box>
            <Button type="submit" variant="contained" color="primary" fullWidth>
              Log Activity
            </Button>
          </form>
        </div>
      </Container>
    </Layout>
  );
};

export default LogForm;

    • There's a duplicate route for /signUp in the App component.

  6. Correct Usage of Functions and Hooks:

    • Make sure all functions and hooks are defined and utilized correctly.

Corrected Code:

Here is the corrected code for your App, LogForm, and Dashboard components.

App.js:

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import './App.css';
import LogForm from './components/LogForm';
import Dashboard from './components/Dashboard';
import Workout from './components/Workout';
import Contact from './components/Contact';
import { BrowserRouter as Router, Routes, Route, Navigate } from 'react-router-dom';
import SignIn from './components/SignIn';
import SignUp from './components/SignUp';
import About from './components/About';

function App() {
  const [isLoggedIn, setIsLoggedIn] = useState(false);
  const [activities, setActivities] = useState([]);

  const addActivity = (newActivity) => {
    setActivities((prevActivities) => [...prevActivities, newActivity]);
  };

  const handleLogin = () => {
    setIsLoggedIn(true);
  };

  const handleLogout = () => {
    localStorage.removeItem('user');
    localStorage.setItem('isLoggedIn', 'false');
    setIsLoggedIn(false);
  };

  return (
    <Router>
      <Routes>
        <Route
          path="/"
          element={isLoggedIn ? <Dashboard activities={activities} /> : <Navigate to="/signIn" />}
        />
        <Route path="/work" element={isLoggedIn ? <Workout /> : <Navigate to="/signIn" />} />
        <Route path="/contact" element={isLoggedIn ? <Contact /> : <Navigate to="/signIn" />} />
        <Route path="/add" element={isLoggedIn ? <LogForm addActivity={addActivity} /> : <Navigate to="/signIn" />} />
        <Route path="/signIn" element={<SignIn onLogin={handleLogin} />} />
        <Route path="/signUp" element={<SignUp />} />
        <Route path="/about" element={<About />} />
      </Routes>
    </Router>
  );
}

export default App;

Dashboard.js:

jsx
import React from 'react';
import { Card, CardContent, Typography, Button } from '@mui/material';
import Layout from './Layout';
import { Link } from 'react-router-dom';

const Dashboard = ({ activities }) => {
  const totalSteps = activities.reduce((sum, activity) => sum + Number(activity.steps), 0);
  const totalCalories = activities.reduce((sum, activity) => sum + Number(activity.calories), 0);
  const totalWorkoutTime = activities.reduce((sum, activity) => sum + Number(activity.workoutTime), 0);

  return (
    <Layout>
      <div className='dash-container'>
        <h1>Fitness Tracker</h1>
        <Link to='/add'>
          <Button variant="contained">
            Add Activity
          </Button>
        </Link>

        {/* Cards for Total Counts */}
        <div className='card-container'>
          <Card className='cards'>
            <CardContent>
              <Typography variant="h6" color='blue'>Total Steps</Typography>
              <Typography variant="body1">{totalSteps}</Typography>
            </CardContent>
          </Card>

          <Card className='cards'>
            <CardContent>
              <Typography variant="h6" color='blue'>Total Calories Burned</Typography>
              <Typography variant="body1">{totalCalories}</Typography>
            </CardContent>
          </Card>

          <Card className='cards'>
            <CardContent>
              <Typography variant="h6" color='blue'>Total Workout Time</Typography>
              <Typography variant="body1">{totalWorkoutTime} mins</Typography>
            </CardContent>
          </Card>
        </div>

        {/* Cards for each activity */}
        <div className='card-container'>
          {activities.length > 0 ? (
            activities.map((activity, index) => (
              <Card key={index} variant="outlined" className='cards'>
                <CardContent>
                  <Typography variant="h6">{activity.date}</Typography>
                  <Typography><b>Steps:</b> {activity.steps}</Typography>
                  <Typography><b>Calories Burned:</b> {activity.calories}</Typography>
                  <Typography><b>Workout Time:</b> {activity.workoutTime} mins</Typography>
                </CardContent>
              </Card>
            ))
          ) : (
            <Typography>No activities logged yet.</Typography>
          )}
        </div>
      </div>
    </Layout>
  );
};

export default Dashboard;

LOgForm.js:

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import { TextField, Button, Box, Container } from '@mui/material';
import { Layout } from './Layout';
import sideImg from '../assets/bg.jpeg'; // Ensure this path is correct

const LOgForm = ({ addActivity }) => {
  const [formState, setFormState] = useState({
    date: '',
    steps: '',
    calories: '',
    workoutTime: ''
  });

  const handleChange = (e) => {
    setFormState({
      ...formState,
      [e.target.name]: e.target.value
    });
  };

  const handleSubmit = (e) => {
    e.preventDefault();
    if (typeof addActivity === 'function') {
      addActivity(formState);
      setFormState({ date: '', steps: '', calories: '', workoutTime: '' });
    } else {
      console.error('addActivity is not a function');
    }
  };

  return (
    <Layout>
      <Container className="form-wrapper">
        <div className="image-container">
          <img src={sideImg} alt="Fitness" />
        </div>
        <div className="form-container">
          <h1>Add Daily Activity</h1>
          <form onSubmit={handleSubmit}>
            <Box mb={2}>
              <TextField
                label="Date"
                name="date"
                value={formState.date}
                onChange={handleChange}
                fullWidth
                margin="normal"
              />
              <TextField
                label="Steps Taken"
                name="steps"
                value={formState.steps}
                onChange={handleChange}
                fullWidth
                margin="normal"
              />
              <TextField
                label="Calories Burned"
                name="calories"
                value={formState.calories}
                onChange={handleChange}
                fullWidth
                margin="normal"
              />
              <TextField
                label="Workout Time (mins)"
                name="workoutTime"
                value={formState.workoutTime}
                onChange={handleChange}
                fullWidth

            <Button type="submit" variant="contained" color="primary" fullWidth>
              Log Activity
            </Button>
          </form>
        </div>
      </Container>

  );
};

                    </CardContent>

            </Grid>
          </Grid>
        </Grid>

  const [selectedDate, setSelectedDate] = useState(null);

    <Layout>
      <div className="workout-container">
        <Typography variant="h4" gutterBottom>
          Available Workouts
        </Typography>
        <Grid container spacing={3}>
          <Grid item xs={12} md={4}>
            <Box sx={{ padding: 2 }}>
              <LocalizationProvider dateAdapter={AdapterDayjs}>
                <DateCalendar
                  value={selectedDate}
                  onChange={(newDate) => setSelectedDate(newDate)}
                />
              </LocalizationProvider>
            </Box>
          </Grid>
          <Grid item xs={12} md={8}>
            <Grid container spacing={3}>
              {workouts.map((workout) => (
                <Grid item xs={12} sm={6} md={4} key={workout.id}>
                  <Card>
                    <CardContent>
                      <Typography variant="h5" component="div">
                        {workout.name}
                      </Typography>
                      <Typography variant="body2" color="textSecondary">
                        Duration: {workout.duration}
                      </Typography>
                      <Typography variant="body2" color="textSecondary">
                        Calories Burned: {workout.calories}
                      </Typography>
                    </CardContent>
                  </Card>
                </Grid>
              ))}
            </Grid>
          </Grid>
        </Grid>
      </div>
    </Layout>
  );
};

export default WOrkout;

ChatGPT said:

To make your Dashboard component more stylish and incorporate icons related to workouts, you can use Material-UI components and icons to enhance the visual appeal. Heres how you can update your component:

Updated Dashboard Component

  1. Use Icons: Add icons to represent different metrics like total calories, workout time, and individual activities.
  2. Styling with Material-UI: Use Material-UI's Box component for layout, and add some styling to make the cards look more modern.

Heres the updated code:

jsx
import React from 'react';
import { Card, CardContent, Typography, Box, Button } from '@mui/material';
import { Layout } from './Layout';
import { Link } from 'react-router-dom';
import LocalFireDepartmentIcon from '@mui/icons-material/LocalFireDepartment'; // For calories
import FitnessCenterIcon from '@mui/icons-material/FitnessCenter'; // For workout time
import DirectionsRunIcon from '@mui/icons-material/DirectionsRun'; // For steps

const Dashboard = ({ activities }) => {
  // Calculate totals
  const totalSteps = activities.reduce((sum, activity) => sum + Number(activity.steps), 0);
  const totalCalories = activities.reduce((sum, activity) => sum + Number(activity.calories), 0);
  const totalWorkoutTime = activities.reduce((sum, activity) => sum + Number(activity.workoutTime), 0);

  return (
    <Layout>
      <Box className="dash-container" sx={{ textAlign: 'center', padding: '2rem' }}>
        <Typography variant="h4" gutterBottom>
          Fitness Tracker
        </Typography>
        <Link to='/add' style={{ textDecoration: 'none' }}>
          <Button variant="contained" color="primary" sx={{ marginBottom: '1rem' }}>
            Add Activity
          </Button>
        </Link>

        {/* Cards for Total Counts */}
        <Box className="card-container" sx={{ display: 'flex', justifyContent: 'center', gap: '1rem', marginBottom: '2rem' }}>
          <Card className="cards" sx={{ minWidth: 200, padding: '1rem', textAlign: 'center' }}>
            <CardContent>
              <LocalFireDepartmentIcon fontSize="large" color="secondary" />
              <Typography variant="h6" color="textSecondary">Total Calories Burned</Typography>
              <Typography variant="body1">{totalCalories}</Typography>
            </CardContent>
          </Card>

          <Card className="cards" sx={{ minWidth: 200, padding: '1rem', textAlign: 'center' }}>
            <CardContent>
              <FitnessCenterIcon fontSize="large" color="primary" />
              <Typography variant="h6" color="textSecondary">Total Workout Time</Typography>
              <Typography variant="body1">{totalWorkoutTime} mins</Typography>
            </CardContent>
          </Card>
        </Box>

        {/* Cards for Each Activity */}
        <Box className="card-container" sx={{ display: 'flex', flexWrap: 'wrap', gap: '1rem', justifyContent: 'center' }}>
          {activities.length > 0 ? (
            activities.map((activity, index) => (
              <Card key={index} variant="outlined" className="cards" sx={{ minWidth: 200, padding: '1rem', textAlign: 'center' }}>
                <CardContent>
                  <Typography variant="h6" gutterBottom>{activity.date}</Typography>
                  <Typography><DirectionsRunIcon color="action" /> <b>Steps:</b> {activity.steps}</Typography>
                  <Typography><LocalFireDepartmentIcon color="action" /> <b>Calories Burned:</b> {activity.calories}</Typography>
                  <Typography><FitnessCenterIcon color="action" /> <b>Workout Time:</b> {activity.workoutTime} mins</Typography>
                </CardContent>
              </Card>
            ))
          ) : (
            <Typography>No activities logged yet.</Typography>
          )}
        </Box>
      </Box>
    </Layout>
  );
};

export default Dashboard;

Key Changes and Enhancements:

  1. Icons:

    • LocalFireDepartmentIcon: Represents total calories burned.
    • FitnessCenterIcon: Represents workout time.
    • DirectionsRunIcon: Represents steps taken.

  2. Box Component: Used Box from Material-UI to manage layout and spacing. This helps with responsive design and makes the layout cleaner.

  3. Styling:

    • Cards: Updated the Card component styles to make them more visually appealing with padding and center alignment.
    • Button: Styled the "Add Activity" button to look more distinct.

  4. Flexbox Layout: Using Flexbox for card-container to ensure the cards are properly aligned and responsive.

Additional Tips:

  • Custom Styles: You can further customize the styles with your theme or additional CSS if needed.
  • Responsive Design: Ensure the cards and other components are responsive by adjusting sx properties for different screen sizes.
  • Dynamic Icons: You could dynamically render different icons for different types of activities if needed.

These changes will make your Dashboard more visually appealing and easier to use.

const Dashboard = ({ activities }) => {

  return (

                  <Typography variant="body1">{totalWorkoutTime} mins</Typography>
                </Grid>
                <Grid item>
                  <FitnessCenterIcon fontSize="large" color="primary" />

To add a gap between the <Typography> component and the <p> tag, you can use margin or padding styles. Heres how you can adjust the margin on the <p> tag to create a visual gap between the two elements.

Updated Code with a Gap

Add a margin-top to the <p> tag to create space between the <Typography> and the <p> tag.

jsx
<CardContent>
  <Grid container alignItems="center" justifyContent="space-between">
    {/* Left Side: Text Content */}
    <Grid item>
      <Typography variant="h6" color="textSecondary">Calories Burned</Typography>
      <Typography variant="body1">{totalCalories}</Typography>
      
      {/* Add the <p> tag here with margin-top */}
      <p style={{ margin: '8px 0 0 0', color: '#555' }}>Keep pushing your limits!</p>
    </Grid>
    
    {/* Right Side: Icon */}
    <Grid item>
      <LocalFireDepartmentIcon fontSize="large" color="secondary" />
    </Grid>
  </Grid>
</CardContent>

Explanation:

  • margin: '8px 0 0 0':
    • This style applies a top margin of 8px to the <p> tag. The values in margin are in the order: top, right, bottom, left.
    • Setting the top margin to 8px creates the space above the <p> tag, separating it from the Typography component above.
    • The other three margins (right, bottom, left) are set to 0 to ensure no additional space is added on those sides.

Alternative Using Typography Component:

If you want to maintain consistency with Material-UI styling, you could replace the <p> tag with another Typography component and use the gutterBottom prop to automatically add spacing.

jsx
<Grid item>
  <Typography variant="h6" color="textSecondary">Calories Burned</Typography>
  <Typography variant="body1" gutterBottom>{totalCalories}</Typography>
  <Typography variant="body2" color="textSecondary">Keep pushing your limits!</Typography>
</Grid>
  • gutterBottom: This prop adds a bottom margin to the Typography component, ensuring a consistent space below it.

Either method will effectively create a visual gap between your text elements, enhancing readability and design clarity.

To add a graph to visualize the calories data, you can use a library like Chart.js with react-chartjs-2, which provides a set of React components for Chart.js. Heres how you can integrate a bar chart to display the calories data alongside your cards.

Step-by-Step Guide to Adding a Graph

  1. Install react-chartjs-2 and chart.js: Make sure to install the required packages if you havent already:

    bash
    npm install react-chartjs-2 chart.js

  2. Import the necessary components: Import the Bar component from react-chartjs-2 and configure your chart.

  3. Prepare your chart data: Create a dataset based on the calories data.

  4. Add the graph component to your code: Include the Bar chart in your component and configure it to display the calories data.

Updated Code with a Graph

Heres how you can integrate the Bar chart into your existing Dashboard component:

jsx
import React from 'react';
import { Card, CardContent, Typography, Grid, Button } from '@mui/material';
import { Layout } from './Layout';
import { Link } from 'react-router-dom';
import LocalFireDepartmentIcon from '@mui/icons-material/LocalFireDepartment';
import { Bar } from 'react-chartjs-2';
import { Chart as ChartJS, CategoryScale, LinearScale, BarElement, Title, Tooltip, Legend } from 'chart.js';

ChartJS.register(CategoryScale, LinearScale, BarElement, Title, Tooltip, Legend);

const Dashboard = ({ activities }) => {
  // Calculate totals
  const totalCalories = activities.reduce((sum, activity) => sum + Number(activity.calories), 0);
  
  // Prepare data for the bar chart
  const chartData = {
    labels: activities.map((activity, index) => `Activity ${index + 1}`), // X-axis labels
    datasets: [
      {
        label: 'Calories Burned',
        data: activities.map(activity => Number(activity.calories)), // Y-axis data
        backgroundColor: 'rgba(255, 99, 132, 0.5)',
        borderColor: 'rgba(255, 99, 132, 1)',
        borderWidth: 1,
      },
    ],
  };

  const chartOptions = {
    responsive: true,
    plugins: {
      legend: {
        position: 'top',
      },
      title: {
        display: true,
        text: 'Calories Burned Per Activity',
      },
    },
  };

  return (
    <Layout>
      <div className='dash-container'>
        <h1>Fitness Tracker</h1>
        <Link to='/add'>
          <Button variant="contained">Add Activity</Button>
        </Link>

        {/* Graph for Calories Data */}
        <div className='graph-container'>
          <Bar data={chartData} options={chartOptions} />
        </div>

        {/* Cards for Total Counts */}
        <div className='card-container'>
          <Card className='cards'>
            <CardContent>
              <Grid container alignItems="center" justifyContent="space-between">
                <Grid item>
                  <Typography variant="h6" color="textSecondary">Calories Burned</Typography>
                  <Typography variant="body1">{totalCalories}</Typography>
                  <p style={{ margin: '8px 0 0 0', color: '#555' }}>Keep pushing your limits!</p>
                </Grid>
                <Grid item>
                  <LocalFireDepartmentIcon fontSize="large" color="secondary" />
                </Grid>
              </Grid>
            </CardContent>
          </Card>
        </div>

        {/* Cards for each activity */}
        <div className='card-container'>
          {activities.length > 0 ? (
            activities.map((activity, index) => (
              <Card key={index} variant="outlined" className='cards'>
                <CardContent>
                  <Typography variant="h6">{activity.date}</Typography>
                  <Typography><b>Steps:</b> {activity.steps}</Typography>
                  <Typography><b>Calories Burned:</b> {activity.calories}</Typography>
                  <Typography><b>Workout Time:</b> {activity.workoutTime} mins</Typography>
                </CardContent>
              </Card>
            ))
          ) : (
            <Typography>No activities logged yet.</Typography>
          )}
        </div>
      </div>
    </Layout>
  );
};

export default Dashboard;

Explanation:

  1. Bar Component: This is the chart component from react-chartjs-2 used to display bar charts.

  2. chartData and chartOptions: These are configuration objects for the chart. chartData defines the data set, including labels and the data itself, while chartOptions configures the chart's appearance, such as title and legend.

  3. Graph Container: A <div> with a class graph-container is added to house the bar chart. You can add custom CSS for styling this container as needed.

  4. Chart Integration: The bar chart is placed above the total count cards, but you can adjust its placement as desired.

Additional Tips:

  • Styling: Adjust the CSS for .graph-container to style the chart's container.
  • Responsive Design: The responsive: true option ensures that the chart resizes based on the screen size. You may need to tweak further for mobile devices.
  • Dynamic Labels: If each activity has a specific name or date, you can modify the labels array in chartData to reflect those names.

This setup provides a visual representation of the calories burned per activity, making your dashboard more informative and engaging.

To integrate a pie chart using the PieChart component from @mui/x-charts into your Dashboard component, we can create a separate component for the pie chart and then import and use it in your Dashboard. Below is the step-by-step integration:

Step 1: Install @mui/x-charts

First, you need to ensure that the @mui/x-charts library is installed in your project. Run the following command:

bash
npm install @mui/x-charts

Step 2: Create a Pie Chart Component

Create a new file named BasicPie.jsx (or a similar name) for the pie chart component:

BasicPie.jsx

jsx
import * as React from 'react';
import { PieChart } from '@mui/x-charts/PieChart';

const BasicPie = ({ data }) => {
  return (
    <PieChart
      series={[
        {
          data,
        },
      ]}
      width={400}
      height={200}
    />
  );
};

export default BasicPie;

import React from 'react';
import { Card, CardContent, Typography, Grid, Button } from '@mui/material';
import { Layout } from './Layout';
import { Link } from 'react-router-dom';
import LocalFireDepartmentIcon from '@mui/icons-material/LocalFireDepartment';
import DirectionsRunIcon from '@mui/icons-material/DirectionsRun';
import BasicPie from './BasicPie'; // Import the pie chart component
import { Bar } from 'react-chartjs-2';
import { Chart as ChartJS, CategoryScale, LinearScale, BarElement, Title, Tooltip, Legend } from 'chart.js';

ChartJS.register(CategoryScale, LinearScale, BarElement, Title, Tooltip, Legend);

const Dashboard = ({ activities }) => {
  // Calculate totals
  const totalCalories = activities.reduce((sum, activity) => sum + Number(activity.calories), 0);
  const totalSteps = activities.reduce((sum, activity) => sum + Number(activity.steps), 0);
  
  // Prepare data for the bar chart
  const chartData = {
    labels: activities.map((activity, index) => `Activity ${index + 1}`), // X-axis labels
    datasets: [
      {
        label: 'Calories Burned',
        data: activities.map(activity => Number(activity.calories)), // Y-axis data
        backgroundColor: 'rgba(255, 99, 132, 0.5)',
        borderColor: 'rgba(255, 99, 132, 1)',
        borderWidth: 1,
      },
    ],
  };

  const chartOptions = {
    responsive: true,
    plugins: {
      legend: {
        position: 'top',
      },
      title: {
        display: true,
        text: 'Calories Burned Per Activity',
      },
    },
  };

  // Data for the pie chart
  const pieData = [
    { id: 0, value: totalCalories, label: 'Calories Burned' },
    { id: 1, value: totalSteps, label: 'Steps' },
    // Add more data points as needed
  ];

  return (
    <Layout>
      <div className='dash-container'>
        <h1>Fitness Tracker</h1>
        <Link to='/add'>
          <Button variant="contained">Add Activity</Button>
        </Link>

        <div className='graph-container'>
          <Bar data={chartData} options={chartOptions} />
        </div>

        {/* Pie Chart */}
        <div className='graph-container'>
          <BasicPie data={pieData} />
        </div>

        {/* Cards for Total Counts */}
        <div className='card-container'>
          <Card className="cards" sx={{ minWidth: 400, padding: '1rem' }}>
            <CardContent>
              <Grid container alignItems="center" justifyContent="space-between">
                <Grid item>
                  <Typography variant="h6" color="textSecondary">Calories Burned</Typography>
                  <Typography variant="body1">{totalCalories}</Typography>
                  <p style={{ margin: '8px 0 0 0', color: '#555' }}>Total Calories</p>
                </Grid>
                <Grid item>
                  <LocalFireDepartmentIcon fontSize="large" color="secondary" />
                </Grid>
              </Grid>
            </CardContent>
          </Card>

          <Card className="cards" sx={{ minWidth: 400, padding: '1rem' }}>
            <CardContent>
              <Grid container alignItems="center" justifyContent="space-between">
                <Grid item>
                  <Typography variant="h6" color="textSecondary">Steps</Typography>
                  <Typography variant="body1">{totalSteps}</Typography>
                  <p style={{ margin: '8px 0 0 0', color: '#555' }}>Total Steps</p>
                </Grid>
                <Grid item>
                  <DirectionsRunIcon fontSize="large" color="secondary" />
                </Grid>
              </Grid>
            </CardContent>
          </Card>
        </div>

        {/* Cards for each activity */}

          {activities.length > 0 ? (
            activities.map((activity, index) => (
              <Card key={index} variant="outlined" className='cards'>
                <CardContent>
                  <Typography variant="h6">{activity.date}</Typography>
                  <Typography><b>Steps:</b> {activity.steps}</Typography>
                  <Typography><b>Calories Burned:</b> {activity.calories}</Typography>
                  <Typography><b>Workout Time:</b> {activity.workoutTime} mins</Typography>

          )}

};

<p>#legs</p> <p>-Back Squat</p> <p>-30 kg</p> i dont want space between
ChatGPT said:

To ensure that there is no space between the <p> elements, you can adjust the CSS for the paragraph tags. By default, <p> tags have a top and bottom margin. You can remove these margins to have the paragraphs display directly one after the other without any spacing.

Here are a few ways to remove the space between the <p> elements:

Method 1: Inline Styles

You can apply an inline style to each <p> element to remove the margin:

jsx
<p style={{ margin: 0 }}>#legs</p>
<p style={{ margin: 0 }}>-Back Squat</p>
<p style={{ margin: 0 }}>-30 kg</p>

Method 2: CSS Classes

If you prefer using CSS classes, you can create a class that removes the margin and apply it to your <p> elements.

CSS:

css
.no-margin {
  margin: 0;
}

JSX:

jsx
<p className="no-margin">#legs</p>
<p className="no-margin">-Back Squat</p>
<p className="no-margin">-30 kg</p>

Method 3: Styled Components (if you're using them)

If you are using styled-components in your project, you can define a styled paragraph without margin:

jsx
import styled from 'styled-components';

const NoMarginParagraph = styled.p`
  margin: 0;
`;

const Component = () => (
  <>
    <NoMarginParagraph>#legs</NoMarginParagraph>
    <NoMarginParagraph>-Back Squat</NoMarginParagraph>
    <NoMarginParagraph>-30 kg</NoMarginParagraph>
  </>
);

Method 4: Material-UI Typography Component

If you're using Material-UI's Typography component, you can use the paragraph prop and gutterBottom prop to control spacing, but in this case, setting gutterBottom to false will ensure no extra margin is added:

jsx
import { Typography } from '@mui/material';

<Typography paragraph={true} gutterBottom={false}>#legs</Typography>
<Typography paragraph={true} gutterBottom={false}>-Back Squat</Typography>
<Typography paragraph={true} gutterBottom={false}>-30 kg</Typography>

Summary

Choose any of these methods depending on your project setup and styling preference. This will remove the default margin between your <p> elements and ensure they appear without any space between them.

ChatGPT said:

To store and retrieve data from local storage in a React application, you can use the localStorage API provided by the browser. Heres how you can save your activities data to local storage and retrieve it when needed.

Save Data to Local Storage

You need to save the activities data to local storage whenever it changes. Typically, you would do this inside a useEffect hook to ensure it updates whenever the activities state changes.

Retrieve Data from Local Storage

You should retrieve the activities data from local storage when the component mounts. Again, this can be done inside a useEffect hook.

Updated Example

Heres how you can modify your component to handle saving and retrieving data from local storage:

  1. Saving Data to Local Storage:

    Modify your component to save activities to local storage whenever it changes.

  2. Retrieving Data from Local Storage:

    Retrieve activities from local storage when the component mounts.

jsx
import React, { useState, useEffect } from 'react';
import { Card, CardContent, Typography, Grid, Box } from '@mui/material';
import DirectionsRunIcon from '@mui/icons-material/DirectionsRun';

const Dashboard = () => {
  const [activities, setActivities] = useState([]);

  // Retrieve data from local storage when the component mounts
  useEffect(() => {
    const storedActivities = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem('activities')) || [];
    setActivities(storedActivities);
  }, []);

  // Save data to local storage whenever activities change
  useEffect(() => {
    localStorage.setItem('activities', JSON.stringify(activities));
  }, [activities]);

  return (
    <Box className="card-container" sx={{ display: 'flex', flexWrap: 'wrap', gap: '1rem', justifyContent: 'center' }}>
      {activities.length > 0 ? (
        activities.map((activity, index) => (
          <Card key={index} variant="outlined" className="cards" sx={{ minWidth: 200, padding: '1rem' }}>
            <CardContent>
              <Grid container alignItems="center" justifyContent="space-between">
                <Grid item>
                  <Typography variant="h6" gutterBottom>{activity.date}</Typography>
                  <Typography><b>Steps:</b> {activity.steps}</Typography>
                  <Typography><b>Calories Burned:</b> {activity.calories}</Typography>
                  <Typography><b>Workout Time:</b> {activity.workoutTime} mins</Typography>
                </Grid>
                <Grid item>
                  <DirectionsRunIcon fontSize="large" color="action" />
                </Grid>
              </Grid>
            </CardContent>
          </Card>
        ))
      ) : (
        <Typography>No activities logged yet.</Typography>
      )}
    </Box>
  );
};

export default Dashboard;

Explanation

  1. Fetching from Local Storage:

    jsx
    useEffect(() => {
  const storedActivities = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem('activities')) || [];
  setActivities(storedActivities);
}, []);

    This useEffect hook runs only once when the component mounts. It retrieves the activities from local storage and updates the component state.

  2. Saving to Local Storage:

    jsx
    useEffect(() => {
  localStorage.setItem('activities', JSON.stringify(activities));
}, [activities]);

    This useEffect hook runs whenever the activities state changes. It saves the updated activities array to local storage.

By implementing these changes, your activities data will persist across page reloads and browser sessions.

ChatGPT said:

To manage data persistence across your application, you can leverage localStorage to save and retrieve data. This approach ensures that user input is preserved even after refreshing the page.

Here's how you can integrate local storage into both components:

1. LOgForm Component

You need to save the activity data to local storage when a new activity is logged. Additionally, you'll retrieve and display the data in the WOrkout component.

LOgForm Component:

jsx
import React, { useState } from 'react';
import { TextField, Button, Box, Container } from '@mui/material';
import { Layout } from './Layout';
import sideImg from '../assets/bg.jpeg'; // Ensure this path is correct

const LOgForm = ({ addActivity }) => {
  const [formState, setFormState] = useState({
    date: '',
    steps: '',
    calories: '',
    workoutTime: ''
  });

  const handleChange = (e) => {
    setFormState({
      ...formState,
      [e.target.name]: e.target.value
    });
  };

  const handleSubmit = (e) => {
    e.preventDefault();

    // Save activity to local storage
    const existingActivities = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem('activities')) || [];
    existingActivities.push(formState);
    localStorage.setItem('activities', JSON.stringify(existingActivities));

    setFormState({ date: '', steps: '', calories: '', workoutTime: '' });
  };

  return (
    <Layout>
      <Container className="form-wrapper">
        <div className="image-container">
          <img src={sideImg} alt="Fitness" />
        </div>
        <div className="form-container">
          <h1>Add Daily Activity</h1>
          <form onSubmit={handleSubmit}>
            <Box mb={2}>
              <TextField
                type='date'
                label="Date"
                name="date"
                value={formState.date}
                onChange={handleChange}
                fullWidth
                margin="normal"
              />
              <TextField
                label="Steps Taken"
                name="steps"
                value={formState.steps}
                onChange={handleChange}
                fullWidth
                margin="normal"
              />
              <TextField
                label="Calories Burned"
                name="calories"
                value={formState.calories}
                onChange={handleChange}
                fullWidth
                margin="normal"
              />
              <TextField
                label="Workout Time (mins)"
                name="workoutTime"
                value={formState.workoutTime}
                onChange={handleChange}
                fullWidth
                margin="normal"
              />
            </Box>
            <Button type="submit" variant="contained" color="primary" fullWidth>
              Log Activity
            </Button>
          </form>
        </div>
      </Container>
    </Layout>
  );
};

export default LOgForm;

2. WOrkout Component

Retrieve and display the activities from local storage, and show them grouped by date.

WOrkout Component:

jsx
import React, { useState, useEffect } from 'react';
import { Card, CardContent, Typography, Grid, Box } from '@mui/material';
import { LocalizationProvider } from '@mui/x-date-pickers/LocalizationProvider';
import { AdapterDayjs } from '@mui/x-date-pickers/AdapterDayjs';
import { DateCalendar } from '@mui/x-date-pickers/DateCalendar';
import { Layout } from './Layout';
import RunningIcon from '@mui/icons-material/DirectionsRun';
import YogaIcon from '@mui/icons-material/CheckCircleOutline';
import CyclingIcon from '@mui/icons-material/DirectionsBike';

const workouts = [
  { id: 1, name: 'Running', duration: '30 mins', calories: '300', icon: <RunningIcon fontSize="large" /> },
  { id: 2, name: 'Yoga', duration: '60 mins', calories: '200', icon: <YogaIcon fontSize="large" /> },
  { id: 3, name: 'Cycling', duration: '45 mins', calories: '400', icon: <CyclingIcon fontSize="large" /> },
];

const WOrkout = () => {
  const [selectedDate, setSelectedDate] = useState(null);
  const [activities, setActivities] = useState([]);

  // Retrieve data from local storage when the component mounts
  useEffect(() => {
    const storedActivities = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem('activities')) || [];
    setActivities(storedActivities);
  }, []);

  // Filter activities by selected date
  const filteredActivities = activities.filter(activity => activity.date === selectedDate?.format('YYYY-MM-DD'));

  return (
    <Layout>
      <div className="workout-container">
        <Typography variant="h4" gutterBottom>
          Available Workouts
        </Typography>
        <Grid container spacing={3}>
          <Grid item xs={12} md={4}>
            <Box sx={{ padding: 2 }}>
              <LocalizationProvider dateAdapter={AdapterDayjs}>
                <DateCalendar
                  value={selectedDate}
                  onChange={(newDate) => setSelectedDate(newDate)}
                />
              </LocalizationProvider>
            </Box>
          </Grid>
          <Grid item xs={12} md={8}>
            <Grid container spacing={3}>
              {workouts.map((workout) => (
                <Grid item xs={12} sm={6} md={4} key={workout.id}>
                  <Card sx={{ display: 'flex', flexDirection: 'column', height: '100%' }}>
                    <CardContent sx={{ flex: '1 0 auto', display: 'flex', flexDirection: 'column', justifyContent: 'center', alignItems: 'center' }}>
                      {workout.icon}
                      <Typography variant="h5" component="div">
                        {workout.name}
                      </Typography>
                      <Typography variant="body2" color="textSecondary">
                        Duration: {workout.duration}
                      </Typography>
                      <Typography variant="body2" color="textSecondary">
                        Calories Burned: {workout.calories}
                      </Typography>
                    </CardContent>
                  </Card>
                </Grid>
              ))}
            </Grid>
          </Grid>
        </Grid>
        
        {/* Display activities for the selected date */}
        <Box className="activity-container" sx={{ marginTop: 4 }}>
          <Typography variant="h5" gutterBottom>
            Activities for {selectedDate ? selectedDate.format('YYYY-MM-DD') : 'Selected Date'}
          </Typography>
          {filteredActivities.length > 0 ? (
            filteredActivities.map((activity, index) => (
              <Card key={index} variant="outlined" sx={{ marginBottom: 2, padding: '1rem' }}>
                <CardContent>
                  <Typography variant="h6" gutterBottom>Date: {activity.date}</Typography>
                  <Typography><b>Steps:</b> {activity.steps}</Typography>
                  <Typography><b>Calories Burned:</b> {activity.calories}</Typography>
                  <Typography><b>Workout Time:</b> {activity.workoutTime} mins</Typography>
                </CardContent>
              </Card>
            ))
          ) : (
            <Typography>No activities logged for this date.</Typography>
          )}
        </Box>
      </div>
    </Layout>
  );
};

export default WOrkout;

Explanation

  1. Saving Data (LOgForm Component):

    • When the form is submitted, the new activity is saved to local storage along with existing activities.

  2. Fetching and Displaying Data (WOrkout Component):

    • On component mount, the activities are fetched from local storage.
    • The activities are filtered based on the selected date, and the filtered activities are displayed in cards.

These changes ensure that your application retains user input and displays it according to the selected date, providing a complete and persistent user experience.

ChatGPT said:

Sure! Here's a simple example of a homepage layout that includes an image, a heading, a paragraph, and a login button. This example uses Material-UI components for styling.

Homepage Component

jsx
import React from 'react';
import { Container, Typography, Button, Box } from '@mui/material';
import homepageImage from '../assets/homepage-image.jpeg'; // Ensure this path is correct

const HomePage = () => {
  return (
    <Container 
      sx={{ 
        display: 'flex', 
        flexDirection: 'column', 
        alignItems: 'center', 
        justifyContent: 'center', 
        minHeight: '100vh', 
        textAlign: 'center' 
      }}
    >
      <Box 
        component="img" 
        src={homepageImage} 
        alt="Homepage" 
        sx={{ 
          width: '100%', 
          maxWidth: 600, 
          borderRadius: '8px', 
          mb: 3 
        }} 
      />
      <Typography variant="h2" gutterBottom>
        Welcome to Fitness Tracker
      </Typography>
      <Typography variant="body1" paragraph>
        Track your daily fitness activities, monitor your progress, and stay motivated with our easy-to-use fitness tracker. Log your workouts, monitor your steps, calories burned, and much more.
      </Typography>
      <Button 
        variant="contained" 
        color="primary" 
        href="/login" // Link to login page
        sx={{ 
          marginTop: 2, 
          padding: '0.75rem 2rem' 
        }}
      >
        Login
      </Button>
    </Container>
  );
};

export default HomePage;

Explanation

  1. Container: Centers the content vertically and horizontally with a minimum height of the viewport height (100vh).

  2. Box: Displays the image with responsive width and rounded corners. Adjust the maxWidth as needed.

  3. Typography: Displays the heading and paragraph with appropriate styling.

  4. Button: A contained button with primary color that links to the login page.

Styling and Assets

Make sure to adjust the homepageImage path to point to your actual image file. You can also customize the styling further to fit your needs.

This component will create a welcoming homepage with an image, heading, paragraph, and a button to navigate to the login page.
